div1.head: Jim to Mlle. Marcelle Guerin July 8th 1915
div1.p:
I have just come in from night duty and found your very delightful letter in the bureau where I reported before going for coffee. I put your letter in my pocket and went over to my room, washed up a bit, and sat down to read it. I had intended going to bed for it was hard work all day yesterday, and all night, but somehow your letter, the touch it brought me of yourself, has rested me and now I want to write you instead of resting. Its wonderful how much content and happiness your letters bring me — all except those parts where I find how hard and disagreeable some phases of your work are. Still even those recitals add a great deal for they give a bigger meaning to the rest of the letter. I’m awfully sorry you’ve got such a rotten patient on your hands and I hope to goodness something, it doesn’t matter very much what, will relieve you of the task. In this work everyone concerned, the patient, nurse, or doctor, or anyone concerned, [concerned scratched out] have to work in harmony or the task becomes very, very hard. Of course I do not get the disagreeable, long drawn out trials that fall to your lot — your dear, fine
girl, but I deal with certain phases that are sufficient to give me an understanding of how hard it must be. My trouble is with the brancardiers and doctors, not the wounded. The wounded and his regimental infermeries and we conductors are on one side. The hospital outfit on the other. Its so bitterly discouraging sometimes. Take for instance last night. Everyone is tired, and cross. If you have been following the papers you will know why. For two weeks its been that way. Well as I say we’re tired and that doesn’t help matters, but good heavens others have less right to be worn out and they should do their part. There is heavy firing going on. It will be some time before the wounded are brought down. Maybe half and hour, and one lies down in the telephone room up there back of the trenches hoping for a few minutes sleep before another call. Its cold now for the windows were blown out of the place three days ago, and it takes a little while to doze off. There is a faint ring and looking up from the stretcher one is lying on one sees the weary telephonist in the dim light of his candle plug in the connection. Then —
“Monsier Americain, un plesse’ urgent a c -” You get up and go out to the car and whirr [sic]up a long hill to a place in the woods. The poor, hard worked men at the poste de secours are waiting. In the light of the illuminating rockets you see a much bandaged figure on a stretcher and between the reports of artillery you get instructions to go carefully but swiftly. That’s hard, that two kilometers down into town and you figure on every little bump or hole. Sometimes there’s a new shell hole and you hit it. The poor fellow shrieks and you would give anything to have avoided the bump. We get so that we know the easiest way to take all turns and what sides of the road are smoothest, but every second is a strain as we nurse the car down to the Ambulance where the man will be operated on and evacuated the next morning. The cobblestone streets are the hardest proposition and then comes the hospital. You stop and go to the back of the car. The wounded man is groaning softly. You hurry into the bureau to wake up the attendant. “Un couch’ garment bless”[.] The man slowly gets up mumbling about the toughness of the war and slowly ambles back into the
building. Minutes pass. You go out to the car and try and explain the delay to the wounded man. One brancardier comes out. When will the other come, you wonder. He’s careless about that and wants to know if there are many more wounded. Finally you lose all patience. I know I do and think of the other brancardier still sleeping. Finally he comes out. The man is taken into the operating room and examined in a superficial way. They wake up a surgeon. He takes his time and after a short look turns away saying its no use trying to operate and goes back to bed. The man is carried to a side of the room and the brancardiers go out. Oh, that hurts so after you have tried so hard to get the poor fellow down as easily as possible and hoped you could save his life. To have that indifference shown is very aggravating. You go up again after using up all your matches trying to pick out a brancard that isn’t too bloody or broken and find a load waiting. Three couches and two assis. Down the hill you go again and then there’s the same fight to wake up the hospital. (I am taking parts
from last night’s work for its fresh in my memory and typical of other nights) I took the two assis in with me while I went to rout out the brancardiers. In the corner of the room the poor fellow I had brought before was making hideous noises. He seemed pitiful [sic] dying there all alone, and when I lit a match the two assis looked at him in a shocked sort of way. I went out to my couches. There was a long delay getting the men out. One was a trepan case and I said I’d take him down eight kilometers where a young doctor in a second evacuation hospital would take care of him all right. “Oh we do all that here” said a brancardier and disappeared with the jolting stretcher. They didn’t return for a long time. The remaining man and I passed the time cussing the gang out. “Here we go and get all shot to pieces and then they treat us like cochons” he said. When the brancardiers came out he handed them a bit of his mind “Remember you’re not the only one,” they said and that got me furious. “You g - d - bunch of embusques. You sit around here all day and raise - h - when a wounded man is the cause of some
work, just as if you blamed him for it. I hope to heavens you all get sent up and get a taste of it yourself.” I said all that in English but from the tone and the word embusques they got my meaning perfectly and for the rest of the night things went better.

It is disheartening you know. When you come down from all the hellish surroundings of the fight with a man who has sacrificed himself, right under your eyes as it were. You feel as if a whole lot was due when you get to the peace and comparative quiet of the town, and then when the poor fellow is treated as if he were a burden it nearly makes you cry. Oh I know how it is. There are thousand and thousands and its impossible to give much attention, but it could be very much different at a certain ambulance I know of. I’m accustomed to all the suffering myself and a bit hardened but I try to give every wounded man the best I can do in the circumstances. Of the fifty two I brought down last night I didn’t forget a bump on any trip and watched just as carefully each time.
Anyone, of course, would do that and so its but natural that one expects people in other departments to at least try and do their best.

I suppose I sound very gloomy. Forgive me for getting off on all that strain. You’ve got enough disagreeable things to bother about. I guess I’m just cross and sleepy. Next time I won’t write until I’m in a better humor.

We had a regular 4th of July celebration. The noise was all free and there was plenty of it, and as an extra the Boches gave us a little bombardment. We had a regular banquet with various sorts of wine glasses we found in the caserne; flowers in projectile vases, paper napkins, flags and various sorts of liquid refreshment. A chef from New York, who is with the troops, prepared the meal for us. Captain Wall the aviator and Noel as well were guests. In the lamp light the varied collection of uniforms was quite effective. It seemed queer to be dining in that way 1,400 yards from the German trenches. Calls kept coming in and we left in turn. One of the fellows recited Gunga Din and during it we heard the roar
of artillery and saw the flashes of guns. It was quite realistic. We all did various stunts and the evening was a great success.

I told you didn’t I that some of the tent section cars have been detached and now do our evacuation to points below the fighting zone. They can’t come any nearer than our old base and we run on down with a fatherly air, to put wounded in the hospital there. It must make them furious. They’re funny to watch. Yesterday in passing thru [sic] the old base some of us were in time to get there as some shells landed and the new crowd was just as excited as could be. They were like a crowd of kids. “Oh Gee we’re in the war” stuff — and they’re still talking about it I guess.
I like Lovell better every day. He’s a real man all the way through. His nerve is fine. He says he’ll stick it out. He and our chief are the best we have. There are three lemons in the outfit.
I’ll write soon again. You’re a peach to write me at such length as you did.
